thread.title: World War II Museum will offer half-price tickets to Louisianians
thread.title_full: World War II Museum will offer half-price tickets to Louisianians | NOLA.com

author: John Pope, NOLA.com | The Times-Picayune
title: World War II Museum will offer half-price tickets to Louisianians
text:
Louisiana residents visiting the National World War II Museum during September will be charged $12 apiece instead of $24.
This applies only to people who buy tickets at the museum, spokeswoman Michelle Moore said. While it includes group admissions, each visitor is limited to four tickets, she said.
General admission covers everything but "Beyond All Boundaries," the multimedia spectacle about the war that Tom Hanks produced, and a simulated submarine ride aboard the U.S.S. Tang. Each of those attractions will cost $5 extra, she said.
The museum at 945 Magazine St. is open daily from 9 a.m. to 5 p.m., including Labor Day.
With a general-admission ticket, visitors can see exhibits such as "Fighting for the Right to Fight," which shows what African-Americans faced during World War II, and "Road to Berlin: European Theater Galleries," which uses photos, videos and artifacts to trace developments in the European Theater.
The museum, which was opened in June 2000, is one of New Orleans' most popular attractions. According to museum figures, it attracted 515,000 visitors last year, 14 percent more than it drew in 2013.
